image.altText: Swimmers at Bondi Beach

props.synopsis: The current El Niño phase of the Pacific Ocean is forecast to peak during the coming months as one of the strongest on record, laying the platform for unprecedented global temperatures through 2024.

title.children: El Niño reaches 'strong' intensity – meaning a scorching 2024 ahead for the planet

image.altText: Mum with baby son sitting on lap. Legs of other children in foreground.

props.synopsis: Stuck on the state's ever-growing public housing wait list, Geraldton mum Dena Comeagain says the sight of boarded up homes in the region leaves her deeply frustrated.

title.children: As Dena's wait for a 'safe haven' for her baby continues, almost 1,400 public houses across WA sit empty

image.altText: israeli soldiers can be seen roaming a courtyard littered with tents

props.synopsis: The World Health Organization says that Israel's ongoing raid of Gaza's Al-Shifa hospital is "totally unacceptable", as the first fuel since October 7 begins to trickle into the enclave after Israel's grants approval.

title.children: IDF claims to find Hamas 'command centre' in Al-Shifa hospital as WHO calls raid 'totally unacceptable'

image.altText: Villawood Immigration Detention Centre

props.synopsis: The federal government is proposing the use of ankle bracelets and curfews to monitor 83 people released from immigration detention last week, in emergency legislation rushed into Federal Parliament.

title.children: Ankle bracelets, curfews proposed for people released from immigration detention after High Court ruling

image.altText: Peter Dutton grins in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: The day began with a clear sign the opposition leader was feeling confident: he held his first press conference in Parliament House in more than three months. It ended on a different note, writes David Speers.

title.children: Dutton had a plan — but it didn't pan out quite the way he might have hoped

image.altText: Adrian Ashenden sits next to his wife on an armchair in their home.

props.synopsis: Optus is facing growing scrutiny after some triple-0 calls failed during its unprecedented outage.

title.children: 'The phone was totally dead': Triple-0 issues for Optus customer who collapsed

image.altText: A soldier looking on, as a large plume of smoke rises in the distance.

props.synopsis: For the first time, Russia concedes "small groups" of Ukrainian forces are in a small town on the side of the Dnipro River that it has occupied since March 2022.

title.children: Ukrainian troops cross crucial river and capture fresh ground, Russia admits

image.altText: A North Korean man in glasses and a black suit with a North Korean woman in a grey suit

props.synopsis: If North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un meets an untimely end, these experts say there's one clear successor.

title.children: She's Kim Jong Un's 'most trusted' advisor, and this expert says she has a 'sardonic, nasty streak'

image.altText: A Navy coin superimposed over a picture of the sea with helicopters nearby.

props.synopsis: A commanding officer of an Australian warship is removed from his position while an inquiry begins into alleged "unacceptable behaviour" involving alcohol, which is prohibited when Navy personnel are at sea.

title.children: Australian warship commander removed following alcohol incident

image.altText: A group of protesters shout, wave Palestinian flags and hold signs that say "freedom for Palestine"

props.synopsis: British Opposition Labour Party Leader Keir Starmer is under pressure after nearly a third of his party members voted with another opposition party to demand the government call for a ceasefire in the Israel-Hamas conflict.

title.children: More than 50 UK Labour MPs defy leader to back Gaza ceasefire

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations Security Council has overcome a deadlock in its search for a resolution to the Israel-Gaza war. It called for urgent and extended humanitarian pauses in fighting between Israel and Palestinian Hamas militants in the Gaza Strip for a "sufficient number of days" to allow humanitarian aid access. The 15-member council saw four unsuccessful attempts to take action last month, to adopt a resolution that also calls for the immediate and unconditional release of all hostages held by Hamas. The United States, Russia and Britain, who are council veto-powers, abstained from the vote on the resolution drafted by Malta. The remaining 12 members voted in favor. Russia failed in a last minute bid to amend the resolution to include a call for an immediate humanitarian truce leading to a cessation of hostilities. The council stalemate has largely been centered on whether to call for a humanitarian pause or a ceasefire. A pause is generally considered less formal and shorter than a ceasefire, which has to be agreed by the warring parties. The United States has backed pauses, while Russia has pushed for a ceasefire. The resolution also does not condemn the actions of Hamas — a point of contention for Israel's ally, the United States, and Britain. The council called "for urgent and extended humanitarian pauses and corridors throughout the Gaza Strip for a sufficient number of days to enable … the full, rapid, safe, and unhindered humanitarian access." The resolution demands compliance with international law, specifically the protection of civilians, especially children. It also calls on all parties not to deprive civilians in Gaza of basic services and humanitarian aid needed for their survival, welcomes the initial, limited deliveries of aid but calls for that to be increased. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN Security Council settles on a call for pauses in Gaza fighting for aid after five failed attempts

. A pause is generally considered less formal and shorter than a ceasefire, which has to be agreed by the warring parties. The United States has backed pauses, while Russia has pushed for a ceasefire.
The resolution also does not condemn the actions of Hamas — a point of contention for Israel's ally, the United States, and Britain.

The council called "for urgent and extended humanitarian pauses and corridors throughout the Gaza Strip for a sufficient number of days to enable … the full, rapid, safe, and unhindered humanitarian access."
The resolution demands compliance with international law, specifically the protection of civilians, especially children.

It also calls on all parties not to deprive civilians in Gaza of basic services and humanitarian aid needed for their survival, welcomes the initial, limited deliveries of aid but calls for that to be increased.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has declared there is no place in Gaza his forces will not reach, after his troops stormed the besieged Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza. Witnesses inside Al-Shifa say that Israeli troops went from building to building, searched between different departments including the basement of the surgical ward and questioned patients, Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn reports. "Witnesses there have described the situation as tense but calm. There has been no reports of any shooting or gunfire inside those hospital buildings and no reports of anybody injured", she said. The Gaza ministry of health has said that the patients who were questioned were terrified and that it's unacceptable for Israel to be operating inside a civilian hospital. "Shifa hospital is still besieged. The occupation soldiers are still on the ground floor and the bedroom floor. They are searching employees, civilians, even the injured and the patients", Dr Mohammad Zaqout from the Gazan health ministry said. "Some of them were unclothed and placed in dehumanising and miserable conditions." In a statement, Israel said its troops were engaged in a gun battle with Hamas militants upon entering the hospital, and that several of those militants were killed. Israel has maintained that its raid is a targeted operation specifically aimed at Hamas infrastructure and weaponry, which the Israeli Defense Force claim to have found inside the hospital, but did not specify where. The IDF released footage of the weaponry they claim to have found but the ABC was not able to independently verify the video. Hamas has maintained that it does not use the hospital to shield its operations. Watch the full report below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Netanyahu hails Al-Shifa raid as major achievement for military campaign

has declared there is no place in Gaza his forces will not reach, after his troops stormed the besieged
Al-Shifa hospital
in Gaza.
Witnesses inside Al-Shifa say that Israeli troops went from building to building, searched between different departments including the basement of the surgical ward and questioned patients,
Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn
reports.
"Witnesses there have described the situation as tense but calm. There has been no reports of any shooting or gunfire inside those hospital buildings and no reports of anybody injured", she said.
The
Gaza ministry of health
has said that the patients who were questioned were terrified and that it's unacceptable for Israel to be operating inside a civilian hospital.

"Shifa hospital is still besieged. The occupation soldiers are still on the ground floor and the bedroom floor. They are searching employees, civilians, even the injured and the patients", Dr Mohammad Zaqout from the Gazan health ministry said.
"Some of them were unclothed and placed in dehumanising and miserable conditions."
In a statement, Israel said its troops were engaged in a gun battle with Hamas militants upon entering the hospital, and that several of those militants were killed.
Israel has maintained that its raid is a targeted operation specifically aimed at Hamas infrastructure and weaponry, which the
Israeli Defense Force
claim to have found inside the hospital, but did not specify where.
The IDF released footage of the weaponry they claim to have found but the ABC was not able to independently verify the video.
Hamas has maintained that it does not use the hospital to shield its operations.
Watch the full report below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After four failed attempts, the UN Security Council is trying for a fifth time to come up with a resolution on the Israel-Hamas war, but it remains to be seen whether serious divisions can be overcome to produce a consensus on wording. The current draft under negotiation would demand "immediate extended humanitarian pauses" throughout the Gaza Strip to provide civilians with desperately needed aid. It also would demand that "all parties" comply with international humanitarian law that requires the protection for civilians, special protections for children and bans hostage-taking. But the draft, proposed by council member Malta, makes no mention of a ceasefire. It also doesn't refer to Hamas's terrorist attack on Israel on October 7 that killed around 1,200 people and took some 240 others hostage. Nor does it cite Israel's retaliatory air strikes and ground offensive in Gaza that the enclave's health ministry says has killed more than 11,000 Palestinians, two-thirds of them women and children. The 15-member council has been paralyzed since the war began by its internal divisions. This is especially the case between China and Russia, which want an immediate ceasefire, and the United States, Israel's closest ally that has called for humanitarian pauses but objects to any mention of a ceasefire. In the four previous tries, a Brazil-drafted resolution was vetoed by the United States, a US-drafted resolution was vetoed by Russia and China, and two Russian-drafted resolutions failed to get the minimum nine "yes" votes needed for adoption. Several council diplomats said the opposing sides were getting closer. The diplomats insisted on speaking anonymously because the negotiations are supposed to be private. The resolution under consideration says the humanitarian pauses should be: For a sufficient number of days to open corridors for unhindered access by UN, Red Cross and other aid workers to get water, electricity, fuel, food and medical supplies in Allow repair of essential infrastructure Enable urgent rescue and recovery efforts Richard Gowan, UN director for the International Crisis Group, said the Security Council has previously called for ceasefires in wars from the Balkans to Syria "with little or no impact". "A UN ceasefire call would embarrass but not really constrain the Israelis," he said. "But the US clearly feels that even such a symbolic move is too much of a political risk." AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The UN Security Council is trying for a fifth time to adopt a resolution on the Israel-Hamas war

consensus on wording

But the draft, proposed by council member Malta, makes no mention of a
ceasefire
It also doesn't refer to
Hamas's terrorist attack
on Israel on October 7 that killed around 1,200 people and took some 240 others hostage. Nor does it cite Israel's
retaliatory air strikes and ground offensive
in Gaza that the enclave's health ministry says has killed more than 11,000 Palestinians, two-thirds of them women and children.

(AP Photo: Mahmoud Abo Salamah)

China and Russia, which want an immediate ceasefire

the United States,
Israel's closest ally that has

but
objects to any mention of a ceasefire

In the four previous tries, a Brazil-drafted resolution was vetoed by the United States, a US-drafted resolution was vetoed by Russia and China, and two Russian-drafted resolutions failed to get the minimum nine "yes" votes needed for adoption.
Several council diplomats said the opposing sides were
getting closer
. The diplomats insisted on speaking anonymously because the negotiations are supposed to be private.
The resolution under consideration says the humanitarian pauses should be:
For a sufficient number of days to open corridors for unhindered access by UN, Red Cross and other aid workers to get water, electricity, fuel, food and medical supplies in
Allow repair of essential infrastructure
Enable urgent rescue and recovery efforts

"A UN ceasefire call would embarrass but not really constrain the Israelis," he said.
"But the US clearly feels that even such a symbolic move is too much of a political risk."
AP

image.altText: An asian woman sits on a lounge holding her sleeping baby and laughing at something on her phone

props.synopsis: Many perinatal specialists believe that new mothers need more support in the fourth trimester — the 12 weeks after birth. They're turning to social media for it.

title.children: Social media is a 'virtual village' for new mums, providing connection and advice. But there is a downside

image.altText: Troye Sivan accepts an ARIA Award for Song of the Year.

props.synopsis: Australian music's night of nights is here, the 2023 ARIA Awards. Here's the full list of winners in all categories.

title.children: ARIA Awards 2023: Troye Sivan takes home four awards, tearful G Flip wins two — Here's the full list of winners

image.altText: One million hazelnut trees

props.synopsis: The Italian company behind Ferrero Rochers and Nutella is giving up on its farm in southern NSW saying the long-term climate is not conducive to hazelnut farming.

title.children: Confectionery giant Ferrero Group to tear up a million trees, abandoning $70 million hazelnut farm

image.altText: A woman in a peach coloured hospital gown holds three white pills in her left hand

props.synopsis: A national report has found COVID caused one of the biggest drops in antibiotic use in Australia in decades, but fears remain the country is "losing the war" against drug-resistant infection.

title.children: Australia 'losing the war' against drug-resistant infection, despite drop in use of antibiotics

image.altText: Virat Kohli leaps into the air.

props.synopsis: Heartbreak and history combine in Mumbai as New Zealand's dreams are once again crushed deep in a World Cup at the hands of India stars Virat Kohli and Mohammed Shami.

title.children: Kohli makes cricket history as he and Shami shatter New Zealand's World Cup dream

image.altText: India

props.synopsis: Virat Kohli and Shreyas Iyer both hit centuries to help India beat New Zealand and progress into the Cricket World Cup final, but a controversial late pitch switch left a "sour taste" for one former skipper.

title.children: Five quick hits — Pitch switch leaves 'sour taste' as King Kohli helps India put end to New Zealand World Cup campaign

image.altText: Close up of Catherine King

props.synopsis: More than 80 infrastructure projects across the country could be scrapped by the federal government in an effort to contain spending.

title.children: 'High risk' infrastructure project funding to be axed as federal government contains spending

image.altText: Two headshots side by side. Both womens were black jackets and are pictured outdoors.

props.synopsis: Jewish and Muslim students describe how they and their friends have felt targeted on American university campuses, as administrators grapple with how to preserve both free speech and student welfare.

title.children: As US colleges try to contain campus tensions, students like Sabrina and Dua take steps to stay safe

image.altText: Malik lies unconscious in a hospital bed connected to oxygen and other machines.

props.synopsis: A South Australian boy has suffered seizures and heart irregularities during a severe reaction to a vape containing a hallucinogen and the major psychoactive component of cannabis.

title.children: Boy, 14, hospitalised and unresponsive for 15 hours after smoking vape laced with illicit drugs

image.altText: Hail blankets the ground on a rural property.

props.synopsis: Farmers in the state's south are facing delays and significant losses after heavy rain and hail hammered their properties this week.

title.children: WA farmer suffers first hail 'wipe-out' as freak storm wreaks havoc during harvest

image.altText: mariam headshot

props.synopsis: The experience of fleeing war and persecution as a child planted a seed for Mariam Veiszadeh. Now she's one of the most prominent social justice advocates in Australia.

title.children: This advocate needed security when she did a TED talk, but it won't stop her speaking out

image.altText: An illustration of the outlines of four women, the background behind is purple.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory coroner has closed a months-long inquiry into the NT's "domestic violence epidemic". The evidence, at times, left her counsel-assisting "speechless". Watch a summary of the inquiry.

title.children: The coroner examined the NT's 'domestic violence epidemic'. Here's what she heard

image.altText: David, in a wheelchair, speaks to Daniel in a warehouse as Harry Potter costumes and props surround them.

props.synopsis: In the wizarding world, Harry Potter is known as "the boy who lived". In reality, it's Daniel Radcliffe's main stunt double, David Holmes, who is lucky to be alive.

title.children: David Holmes was flying high as a Harry Potter stunt double – until he was paralysed on-set

image.altText: White power drug, sprinkled on reflective surface, with ziplock plastic bag.

props.synopsis: A poisons expert warned a heroin overdose can take place after snorting a "single line" of what users thought was cocaine.

title.children: One dead, two critically ill from heroin overdoses after taking what they thought was cocaine

image.altText: A top-down photograph of a number of individual potato chips laid out on a table

props.synopsis: New data suggests many Australian shoppers are now treating snacks as luxury items, to combat rising grocery prices.

title.children: Are you cutting back on snacks to save money? New research shows around half of us are

image.altText: peter sprinzels

props.synopsis: In 1939, Peter Sprinzels was one of more than 600 Czech children rescued by train — or "kindertransports" —  by a London stockbroker named Sir Nicholas Winton.

title.children: How the 'British Schindler' saved hundreds of Jewish children from the Nazis

image.altText: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak wearing a navy blue suit and maroon tie

props.synopsis: The UK Supreme Court rules the government's scheme to send asylum seekers to Rwanda is unlawful, dealing a massive blow to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's election pledge on immigration.

title.children: Court rules UK government's plan to send asylum seekers to Rwanda is illegal

image.altText: A baby in a white outfit lying on its side coughing

props.synopsis: Australia could be on the verge of a whooping cough outbreak and, contrary to popular belief, it isn't just a disease for parents of young children. Here's what you should know.

title.children: Experts are warning a whooping cough epidemic is 'well overdue', here's who's at risk

image.altText: a woman and a baby on a lounge

props.synopsis: After dipping into her annual leave to stay close to her premature son, Kat Averill is now among advocates calling for an extension to the Paid Parental Leave Scheme.

title.children: 'It should be a very precious time': Parents call for longer leave entitlement after premature births

image.altText: Dead muttonbirds on a beach with the sun going down in the background

props.synopsis: Dead mutton birds have been washing up along Australia's east coast. Known as a "seabird wreck", researchers say they're becoming more common.

title.children: Why are seabirds washing up dead along Australia's coast? Here's what researchers say is happening

image.altText: People walking past vintage cars.

props.synopsis: Research shows a change to cars 40 years ago virtually stopped decades of rising toxic gas levels in the Southern Hemisphere, and led to an unintended benefit for the world's climate.

title.children: How quest for better fuel efficiency in 1980s cars drove a positive change for the climate

image.altText: Four sets of three-toed bird tracks set in rock

props.synopsis: Tracks of 125-million-year-old avian footprints discovered by a volunteer fossil hunter are the earliest-known sign of birds in Australia and the southern hemisphere, researchers say.

title.children: 125-million-year-old bird footprints found on Victorian coastline. But they may soon disappear

image.altText: Two women at a red carpet event

props.synopsis: Celebrities have walked the red carpet before the 2023 ARIA Awards kick off at Sydney's Hordern Pavilion. Here's a look at some of the outfits we've seen.

title.children: ARIA awards red carpet: Bright colours, sleek suits, and a nod to Rihanna's Met Gala outfit
